column4: Okay, this is driving me nuts.  Symlinks to directories on manually mounted drives are disappearing randomly since 8.10.  Possibly some kind of daemon watching mounts?
they should remain but be broken
Why would they be broken?  The drive is still connected.
are you using ln -s /path/to/folder  to create the link?
I have 28 years of *nix experience.  This is not a "I don't understand the filesystem" problem.
The symlinks are being deleted by some process, often while the drive still has files open.
a hard link would vanish when the device was unmounted, ln -s would create a softlink and would stay
I know that.  I am very familiar with ln.
a process watching the whole drive like that sounds a little unnecessary to me so i cant see it being implemented
It appeared right after I (fairly recently) upgraded my desktop to 8.10.  Something is "helpfully" cleaning up links, is my guess...
Yeah, I thought that too.  I just can't think of anything else that might be doing this.  A sshfs mountpoint is doing the game.
i'd log a bug or see if this is a new "feature"

Thanks for trying to assist anyway; it's just hard to search for, as people are constantly asking "why don't links in /dev survive a reboot?" and being responded to, so it's hard to find a good search term for my issue.  :)
